data.title: Union Amicale d'Alsace Lorraine - Femmes Françaises [Friendly Union of Alsace Lorraine - Women of France]

You can embed or download low-resolution images free of charge for private and non-commercial use under the IWM Non-Commercial Licence.

By downloading or embedding any image, you agree to the terms and conditions of the IWM Non Commercial Licence, including your use of the attribution statement specified by IWM. For this item, that is:

Image: IWM (Art.IWM PST 11215)

Accepted Non-commercial Use

Permitted use for these purposes:

Personal use for non-commercial research and private study and other uses under the UK’s exceptions to copyright and those exceptions to copyright in place where the user is located.

Use on websites that are primarily information-led, research-oriented and not behind a paywall.

Use on personal social media accounts, provided the individuals are not promoting themselves commercially.

Non-Commercial educational use for the purpose of teaching and instruction, including internal training.

Downloading audio-visual for non-commercial offline listening or viewing.

Free exhibitions held in venues, which do not charge an entry fee.

If you would like to use IWM collections materials in a way that is not covered above, require a commercial licence, high-resolution copies, or have manipulation requests, please contact the Image and Film Licensing Team. Digital files of films and sound recordings are available at cost depending on intended use.

Embed

HTML: BBCode:

Description

Object description

whole: the main image occupies the majority, with a separate smaller image across the top edge, both held within a black border. The title is integrated and positioned across the top of the main image, in white. The text is integrated and positioned in the lower quarter of the main image, in blue, and in brown. Further text is separate and positioned in the lower quarter, in brown and set against a white background. image: two women and a girl look at a doll being held up by one of the women. It is dressed in traditional French costume and holds a Tricolore. Other dolls lay on the floor and in boxes nearby. The smaller image depicts a variety of dolls, including one dressed in traditional Alsatian costume, and a toy horse. text: UNION AMICALE D'ALSACE LORRAINE Henri Royer Femme Françaises! Hâtez-vous pour que l'année 1918 apporte aux fillettes pauvre une poupée Alsacienne ou Lorraine, un souvenir de nos chéres provinces où les fillettes sont plus malheureuses encore et tendent leurs bras vers la France! VISÉ: No. 10062 LAPINA.IMP.PARIS [additional text strip text follows] Venez acheter vos Cadeaux de Noël et de Nouvel An pour vos enfants pour vos Amis, pour vos Filleuls à la Vente au profit des Soldats Alsaciens-Lorrains engagés dans l'Armée Française qui aura lieu les Jeudi 13, Vendredi 14 et Dimanche 15 Décembre de 2 heures à 6 heures dans la Salle des FÊTES de la MAIRE du Xeme ARRONDISST. 72 Faubourg St Martin Poupées Alsaciennes et Lorraines, Objects d'Art, Gravures, Terres cuites, Porcelaines, Spécialités Alsaciennes et Lorraines, Effets pour Soldats, Objects divers, Produits alimentaires, Étrennes utiles et agréables. Goûter Alsacien. ATTRACTIONS: Musique militaire, auditions d'Artistes des Grands Théâtres, Chants d'Alsace et de Lorraine. Les Souscriptions sont reçues au Comité de Secours aus Soldats alsaciens-lorrains - 28 rue Serpente. PARIS [Friendly Union of Alsace-Lorraine. Women of France! Hurry up so that the year 1918 may bring our poor little girls an Alsace or Lorraine doll, a memory of our dear provinces where the little girls are still more wretched and stretch out their arms towards France! Come and buy your Christmas and New Year gifts for your children, your friends, your godchildren, at the Sale for the benefit of Soldiers from Alsace- Lorraine enrolled in the French Army which will be held on Thursday 13, Friday 14 and Sunday 15 December from 2 to 6 p.m. in the Banqueting Room of the Town Hall of the 10th Arrondissement [address]. Alsace and Lorraine dolls, objets d'art, engravings, terracotta items, porcelain items, Alsatian and Lorraine specialities, items for soldiers, sundry objects, food products, useful and attractive gifts. Alsatian afternoon tea.Attractions: military music, recitals by artists from the major theatres, songs of Alsace and Lorraine. Subscriptions are accepted at the Committee for Aid to Soldiers from Alsace-Lorraine.]

Physical description

VISÉ: No 10062. Additional text strip adhered to bottom edge.

Our collections information

We have over a million object records online, and we are adding to this all the time. Our records are never finished. Sometimes we discover new information that changes what we know about an object, such as who made it or used it. Sometimes we change how an object is interpreted. We sometimes make mistakes in our spelling, transcription or categorisation, or miss information out of our records.

Read more about our collections and the information we hold. Developing our collections information

If you have concerns about the language in this record, or you have information to improve it, please share your feedback.

Our collections information

Please use this form to give us feedback on an object. The form will be sent to our Collections Management Team who will use it to improve our object records. We receive a lot of comments and can't respond to each one, but we do read them all and will respond where we can.

Related content

IWM Q 31065

First World War

10 Surprising Laws Passed During The First World War

The outbreak of war in 1914 brought many new rules and regulations to Britain. The most important of these was the Defence of the Realm Act (DORA), passed on 8 August 1914 ‘for securing public safety’.

First World War

8 Celebrity Air Aces Of The First World War

Aviation was one of the most romanticised elements of the First World War. 'Air aces' in particular achieved celebrity status both during and after the war and their photographs regularly appeared in newspapers. Of the eight aces listed here, seven were killed in action between 1916 and 1918 or died in flying accidents during or after the war.

First World War

Whizz Bangs And Wind-Ups: 10 Tommy Slang Terms

During the First World War, British soldiers used language in inventive and often humorous ways. The words and phrases they used reflected everything from the dull routines of service to the traumas of front line action, often tinged with characteristic black humour and irony.
